title: Capture-seq protocol and TE-reX pipeline guidelines for detection of recombination of repeat elements in short- and long-DNA reads libraries

Generation of biotinylated RNA probes
Timing: 2.5 days
This step contains the instructions to generate by PCR and in vitro transcription the double-stranded PCR template and the biotinylated RNA probes used to enrich for repeat element sequences from genomic DNA samples.
Note: Due to the high repetitiveness of the PCR templates, to minimize the risk of PCR artifacts each ssDNA oligonucleotide is amplified individually.
Dilute the ssDNA oligos in ddH2O to 50 ng/μL in individual wells of two 96-wells plates (96 oligonucleotides for L1HS, 80 oligonucleotides for Alu)
Prepare the following master mix for the first PCR (a 180x mix is sufficient for both plates):
table:files/protocols_protocol_2359_5.csv
Aliquot 24 μL of mix in individual wells of two new 96-well PCR plates, following the same plates design used for the ssDNA oligonucleotides dilution plates in point 1.
Transfer 1 μL (50ng) of ssDNA oligonucleotide from each well of the dilution plates to corresponding wells of the PCR plates, place the plates to a thermocycler and run the first PCR using the following program. We recommend using the indicated number of cycles in order to avoid the formation of PCR artifacts.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2359_6.csv
Prepare the master mix for the second PCR:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2359_7.csv
Aliquot 24 μL of mix in two new 96-well PCR keeping the same plate design as the first PCR and transfer 1 μL from each well of the two plates of the first PCR in the new plates. Run the second PCR with the following program:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2359_8.csv
Pool 2 μL from each well of the second PCR plate in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube and mix well.
Note: The dsDNA PCR samples can be stored at −80°C indefinitely.

Run 100 μL of pooled dsDNA on a 1% preparative agarose gel in 1x TAE buffer at 10V/cm, cut the expected 122 bp band with a clean, sterile blade and purify the dsDNA using the QIAquick Gel Extraction kit:
Weigh the gel band and add 3 volumes of buffer QG to 1 volume of gel.
Incubate at 50°C for approximately 10 min or until the gel band has completely dissolved. Vortex every 2–3 min to help the gel dissolving in the buffer.
Add 1 gel volume of isopropanol to the sample and mix thoroughly by vortexing.
Transfer the sample in a QIAquick column inserted in a collection tube.
Centrifuge for 1 min in a tabletop centrifuge at maximum speed and discard the flow-through. If the initial volume of the sample exceeds 800 μL (maximum capacity of the column), repeat this step as required.
Add 500 μL of buffer QG to each sample, centrifuge at 21,000 × g for 1 min and discard the flow-through.
Add 750 μL of PE buffer, let the samples sit for 5 min, centrifuge at 21,000 × g for 1 min and discard the flow-through.
Centrifuge the tubes for 1 additional min at 21,000 × g and transfer the columns in clean 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes.
Elute the dsDNA by applying 55 μL of ddH2O directly on the center of the membrane in the column, let the tube sit for 5 min and centrifuge at 21,000 × g for 1 min.
Repeat the previous step once more for a total of 2 elutions and a final total volume of ∼100 μL.
Measure the concentration of the purified by Nanodrop or Qubit.
Note: the purified dsDNA oligonucleotides pool can be stored at −80°C indefinitely.

Prepare the following mix to perform the in vitro transcription of the biotinylated RNA probes using the MEGAscript T7 Transcription Kit:
table:files/protocols_protocol_2359_9.csv
Mix thoroughly and incubate for 4 h–16 h at 37°C.
Add 1 μL of TURBO DNase, mix well and incubate 15 min at 37°C.
Critical: Omitting this step will result in critically reduced enrichment of the target genomic regions due to interference by the dsDNA oligos.
Perform RNA precipitation:
Add 10 μL of NaAc 3M and 300 μL of ethanol 100%. Mix thoroughly and incubate 16 h or for 16 h at −20°C.
Microcentrifuge at 21,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Carefully remove the supernatant and wash the RNA pellet with cold 80% ethanol freshly prepared using RNAse-free ddH2O.
Microcentrifuge at 21,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C and completely remove traces of ethanol from the tubes.
Air dry the RNA pellet for 5 min, add 150 μL of RNAse-free ddH2O and gently pipet up and down until the pellet is completely resuspended.
Perform QC of the purified RNA probes on a Bioanalyzer using the RNA 6000 nano kit. Aliquot the RNA probes in 0.2 mL tubes and store at −80°C.
Note: the RNA probes can be stored at −80°C indefinitely.
Fragmentation, adapters ligation, size selection and PCR enrichment of DNA samples
Timing: 4 h
This step provides instructions to prepare the genomic DNA samples for the enrichment and capture of repeat element sequences using the biotinylated RNA probes.

Note: we recommend using genomic DNA samples that have been purified using the same method, in order to avoid inconsistencies in DNA integrity especially among large batches of samples. The integrity of each sample should be confirmed by agarose gel. Purified genomic DNA should be resuspended in 1X TE (10 mM Tris pH 8.0, 1 mM EDTA) and should have a A260/A280 absorbance ratio of 1.7–1.9. If some samples show signs of partial degradation, the enzymatic fragmentation of these samples should be calibrated separately since performing the capture on samples with different fragments distribution may lead to variable sequencing result.
Note: the protocol in this section has been adapted from the NEBNext Ultra II FS DNA Library Prep Kit manual. Please refer to the original manual for more details.
Note: the following protocol is for genomic DNA input ≥ 100 ng. For inputs ≤ 100 ng, please refer to the NEBNext Ultra II FS DNA Library Prep Kit manual.

Add 3 μL of USER enzyme and incubate at 37°C for 15 min with the lid heater set to 47°C.

Transfer the reaction from step 18 to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube and add 28.5 μL of 0.1X TE to bring the reaction volume to 100 μL. Mix well by vortexing briefly.

Alternatives: If other library construction kits that do not employ enzymatic fragmentation are used, in case a Covaris S2 is available in the lab we suggest the following shearing protocol using the Covaris microtube AFA Fiber Pre-Slit Snap-Cap tubes:
Dilute 1–5μg intact genomic DNA in 130μL H20 or TE and load in Covaris SnapCap tube (avoid introducing air bubbles in the tube).
Shear the DNA using a program to produce a 200bp fragments distribution (Duty cycle 10% - Intensity 5% - Cycler 200, 60 s × 3 times).
After shearing, perform a standard cleanup the DNA with AMPure XP (1.8x ratio). Elute the DNA in 40μL of ddH2O.

When the 65°C (1) stage is completed, place the RNA probes in the block at 72°C.

Transfer the DNA + RNA samples to the 1.5 mL tubes containing each one aliquot of resuspended M-280 beads (165 μL), mix by pipetting up and down and place the tubes for 30 min on a rotating wheel set at a speed sufficient for the tubes content to be mixed gently at each rotation.
Transfer the tubes on a magnetic stand. After 5 min remove the supernatant and place the tubes on a rack.
Add 165 μL of LS buffer at 25°C and mix by pipetting up and down 10 times or vortex for 10 s to resuspend the beads. Incubate at 25°C for 15 min flicking the tubes every 2 min to avoid precipitation of the beads. In the meanwhile, aliquot the HS buffer in a sufficient number of 1.5 mL tubes and transfer them in a thermo block set at 68°C.
Place the tubes on a magnetic stand, wait for 5 min and remove the LS buffer. To each tube add 165 μL of warm HS buffer, vortex for 15 s and incubate the tubes in the thermo block set at 68°C for 10 min. Briefly spin the tubes to collect all material to the bottom, place on a magnetic stand, wait 5 min and remove the supernatant. Add 165 μL of fresh HS buffer at 68°C and repeat for a total of 3x HS buffer washes.
After the third HS buffer wash remove the tubes from the thermo block, spin them briefly and place them on a magnetic stand. After 5 min discard the supernatant.
Add 50 μL of freshly prepared of NaOH 0.1N to each capture library to denature the RNA-DNA hybrids and pipette gently up and down 15 times or until the beads are thoroughly resuspended.

Incubate for 15 min at 25°C occasionally flicking the tubes to avoid precipitation of the beads.

Add 50 μL of Tris-HCl 1M pH 8.0 to each tube to neutralize the NaOH. Mix well by vortexing or pipetting.

Add 180 μL of AMPure XP beads equilibrated at 20°C–25°C for at least 30 min to each sample, vortex for 10 s and let stand at 20°C–25°C for 5 min.

Aligning FASTQ files on reference genome and running TE-reX
Timing: variable, depending on dataset size
This step provides instructions to align the FASTQ files of the sequenced capture libraries on the reference genome and instructions to run the TE-reX pipeline that finds and annotates recombination events from aligned split reads.

Objective: this section provides basic guidance about how to process the FASTQ files from short-reads and long-reads sequencing. The FASTQ files are first run in the TE-reX pipeline and the output files are in MAF format (for more information, visit https://genome.ucsc.edu/FAQ/FAQformat.html[href=https://genome.ucsc.edu/FAQ/FAQformat.html]). The TE-reX output post-processing section provides some simple scripts to convert the output MAF files in a BED-like format that can be used for downstream analyses.
Hardware requirements: the scripts have been tested on Linux-based servers and computing clusters; we recommend at least 32GB or RAM and 8 CPU cores.
Software requirements: TE-reX can be obtained from: https://gitlab.com/mcfrith/te-rex[href=https://gitlab.com/mcfrith/te-rex]. Please read the TE-reX documentation for dependencies and detailed information. Running TE-reX and the post-processing scripts require a standard Linux/Unix OS environment. The latest test of TE-reX and the post-processing scripts has been performed on Debian GNU/Linux 11 (bullseye).
Align the FASTQ files on the reference genome using LAST.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5],6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6],7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]
Note: Please refer to LAST manual and literature for detailed information about genome indexing and generating the “train_file” accessory file. The following is an example command line, assuming LAST has been installed in a standard /home/bin path. We recommend compressing the aligned files to save storage space:
>/home/bin/lastal -D1e9 -p train_file --split /indexed-genome-path/mydb my_library.fastq.gz | /home/bin/last-postmask | gzip > my_aligned_library.maf.gz
Run the TE-reX pipeline on the aligned libraries.
Note: please refer to the TE-reX manual for detailed information about accessory files and parameters. The following is an example command line, assuming that TE-reX has been installed in a standard /home/bin path and that the aligned library and accessory files are in the same path. We recommend to generate the output in a dedicated path:
>/home/bin/te-rex -s 0 -m 1e-04 genome-to-reps.maf reps-to-reps.tab my_aligned_library.maf.gz /my_terex_out/my_terex_out
With this example command line, TE-reX will generate 2 output files in the /my_terex_out/ folder.
my_terex_out-insert.maf
my_terex_out-recomb.maf

Post-processing of TE-reX recomb output
Timing: variable, depending on dataset size
This step provides instructions to convert the .maf format of the TE-reX output files into a BED-like format suitable for downstream analyses.
In order to convert the output files of TE-reX Recomb from the standard MAF to a BED-like format that can be used for downstream analyses we designed 3 scripts for TE-reX Recomb output from short-reads (with and without repeats enrichment) and long-reads datasets sequenced on Illumina and Oxford Nanopore Technologies (ONT) platforms. The scripts are available at https://gitlab.com/mcfrith/te-rex/-/tree/master/bin[href=https://gitlab.com/mcfrith/te-rex/-/tree/master/bin].
The scripts perform a series of transformations on TE-reX Recomb output files:
Convert the multi-line .maf format in single-line, BED-like format where all the information for a given recombination event are contained within the same line.
Collapse PCR duplicates in a single entry.
Filter recombination events based on the mismap score of the respective split reads.
Generate a unique ID for each recombination event based on the RepeatMasker annotations of the recombined repeats and the breakpoint information from the Dfam repeat models.
Count the number of independent reads supporting each recombination event.
Add information about the genomic distance of the recombined repeats (<100Kb, >100Kb, Inter-chromosomal).
Add information about the type of SV theoretically generated by the recombination event (inversion, deletion, duplication).
Generate a list of recombination events found in multiple samples of the datasets and use it to identify singleton recombination events found only in single samples. Depending on the experimental design of the dataset, this may be useful to identify putative polymorphic and somatic recombination events.

The main difference between the scripts for short- and long-reads is the absence of the sequence of the split reads in the long-reads script output files, since its inclusion would make the results harder to consult. The scripts are provided as executable files that can be run from the same folder of the TE-reX Recomb output files. The requirements for the scripts are:
TE-reX Recomb output files (my_out-recomb.maf).
RepeatMasker annotation in BED format.
The RepeatMasker annotation can be downloaded in BED format using the UCSC Table Browser at https://genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgTables[href=https://genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgTables]. The BED file needs to be modified to remove all the underscore (“_”) symbols present in the name of some repeat subfamilies. The RepeatMasker file should have the following structure (“/t” indicates tab separation): chromosome\tstart \tend\tstrand\trepeatname\trepeattype\trepeatfamily.
Below is one line of example:
Field $1: chr1.
Field $2: 67108753.
Field $3: 67109046.
Field $4: +
Field $5: L1P5.
Field $6: LINE.
Field $7: L1.
The scripts can be run as a standard executable in the command line, for example:
>sh te-rex-short-reads.sh repeatmasker.mod.bed ∗-recomb.maf
The scripts will generate in the run folder a “redundant-recomb-events” file and the output files with the extension ".all" (including all recombination events) and “.uniq” (only putative somatic events).
The ‘redundant-recomb-events” files is a list of unique IDs of those recombination events found by TE-reX in n > 1 input .maf files in the exact same configuration (i.e., same repeat elements pairs and same breakpoint position according to Dfam models), together with the count of the number of occurrences (i.e., the number of independent samples in which a given redundant recombination event has been found).
The .all and .uniq files for the short-reads scripts have the following structure:
Field $1: chromosome name of split read A.
Field $2: Start position of breakpoint for split read A.

Field $3: End position of breakpoint for split read A.
Field $4: Strand for split read A.
Field $5: mismap score for split read A.
Field $6: TE-reX Recomb ID for split read A.
Field $7: mapping information for split read A (genomic location and length)
Field $8: chromosome name of split read B.
Field $9: Start position of breakpoint for split read B.
Field $10: End position of breakpoint for split read B.
Field $11: Strand for split read B.
Field $12: mismap score for split read B.
Field $13: TE-reX Recomb ID for split read B.
Field $14: mapping information for split read B (genomic location and length)
Field $15: identity of the recombined repeats according to Dfam models.
Field $16: Sequence of split read A.
Field $17: Sequence of split read B.
Field $18: Fastq ID.
Field $19: Unique ID (Repeat A_Repeat B_Breakpoint A_Breakpoint B)
Field $20: Independent supporting reads count.
Field $21: Genomic distance of recombined repeats (“<100Kb”, “>100Kb”, “Inter”)
Field $22: Sample name.
Field $23: Type of SV generated by the recombination (“inv”, “del”, “dupl”, “Inter”)
The .all and .uniq files for the long-reads script have the following structure:
Field $1: chromosome name of split read A.
Field $2: Start position of breakpoint for split read A.
Field $3: End position of breakpoint for split read A.
Field $4: TE-reX Recomb ID for split read A.
Field $5: mismap score for split read A.
Field $6: length of mapped split read A.
Field $7: chromosome name of split read B.
Field $8: Start position of breakpoint for split read B.
Field $9: End position of breakpoint for split read B.
Field $10: TE-reX Recomb ID for split read B.
Field $11: mismap score for split read B.
Field $12: length of mapped split read B.

Field $13: Fastq ID.
Field $14: Genomic distance of recombined repeats (“<100Kb”, “>100Kb”, “Inter”)
Field $15: Unique ID (Repeat A_Repeat B_Breakpoint A_Breakpoint B)
Field $16: Sample name.
Field $17: Type of SV generated by the recombination (“inv”, “del”, “dupl”, “Inter”)
